snippet: Some of the cars being recalled by General Motors for problems related to the ignition switch that are still being driven by their owners may still pose a danger to the owner and other motorists.
abstract: Rising debate over whether General Motors cars with faulty ignition switches pose a continuing danger reflects growing impatience with company's timetable for repairs, and fact that most of the unrepaired cars remain on the road; GM has maintained, in the nearly two months since it announced it was recalling Cobalts and other small cars, that the vehicles are safe to drive under certain conditions.

byline.original: By HILARY STOUT and RACHEL ABRAMS
byline.contributor: Bill Vlasic, Rebecca R. Ruiz, Danielle Ivory and Alain Delaquérière contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Some of the cars being recalled by General Motors for problems related to the ignition switch that are still being driven by their owners may still pose a danger to the owner and other motorists.

headline.main: Debate Over Risk of Driving G.M.’s Recalled Cars
headline.print_headline: Debate Over Risk of Driving G.M.’s Recalled Cars
